Q17: there are two basic forms of the disease, namely, cutaneous leishmaniasis and visceral leishmaniasis depending on the species of leishmania responsible and the immune response to infection. The cutaneous form tends to heal spontaneously leaving scars which, depending on the species of leishmania responsible, may evolve into diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis, recidivate leishmaniasis, or mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, with disastrous aesthetic consequences for the patient. Visceral leishmaniasis is the most severe form, and it is fatal in almost all cases if left untreated. It may cause epidemic outbreaks with a high mortality rate.

The action of Th1 (interferon gamma-2, tumor necrosis factor alpha) results in cure while action of Th2 cytokines (IL-4, IL-5, and IL-10) results in progression of the disease. In visceral and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, there is an increase in Th2 cytokines; also other Th2 cytokines like IL-13 and transforming growth factor beta have been reported to be produced in visceral leishmaniasis [8]. While in malaria the progression to the disease is due to the action of tumor necrosis factor alpha and IL-6 cytokines [9]."

title: Modelling Interacting Epidemics In Overlapping Populations
abstract: Epidemic modelling is fundamental to our understanding of biological, social and technological spreading phenomena. As conceptual frameworks for epidemiology advance, it important they are able elucidate empirically-observed dynamic feedback phenomena involving interactions amongst pathogenic agents in the form syndemic counter-syndemic effects. In this paper we model dynamics two types epidemics with interaction effects multiple possibly-overlapping populations. We derive a Markov whose fluid limit reduces set coupled SIR-type ODEs. Its numerical solution reveals some interesting multimodal behaviours, as shown case studies.

title: Multiobjective Optimization To A Tb-Hiv/Aids Coinfection Optimal Control Problem
abstract: We consider a recent coinfection model for Tuberculosis (TB), Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection, and Acquired Syndrome (AIDS) proposed in Silva Torres (Discr Contin Dyn Syst 35(9):4639‚Äì4663, 2015). introduce analyze multiobjective formulation of an optimal control problem, where the two conflicting objectives are minimization number HIV-infected individuals with AIDS clinical symptoms coinfected active TB; costs related to prevention treatment HIV and/or TB measures. The approach eliminates some limitations previous works. results numerical study provide comprehensive insights about policies population dynamics resulting from their implementation. Some nonintuitive conclusions drawn. Overall, simulation demonstrate usefulness validity approach.

abstract: This paper presents a co-infection mathematical model of COVID-19 and TB to study their synergistic dynamics. We first investigated the single infection models each disease then dynamics two diseases. Indeed, we calculated basic reproduction number model, studied existence stability equilibrium points. subsequently proved that only exhibit backward forward bifurcations. In addition, performed sensitivity analysis numbers determine which parameters influence them most. Furthermore, applied Pontryagin‚Äôs maximum principle our assess impact use an imperfect vaccine for COVID-19, taken as optimal control strategy. Finally, presented results numerical simulations support theoretical findings.

title: Oscillations And Chaos In Epidemics: A Nonlinear Dynamic Study Of Six Childhood Diseases In Copenhagen, Denmark
abstract: Using traditional spectral analysis and recently developed non-linear methods, we analyze the incidence of six childhood diseases in Copenhagen, Denmark. In three cases, measles, mumps, rubella, dynamics suggest low dimensional chaos. Outbreaks chicken pox, on other hand, conform to an annual cycle with noise superimposed. The remaining diseases, pertussis scarlet fever, remain problematic. real epidemics are compared output a Monte Carlo analog SEIR model for infections. For find substantial agreement between simulations data.

title: Soil-Transmitted Helminths
abstract: Infections caused by soil-transmitted helminthias (STHs) affect over a billion people worldwide, causing anaemia and having large social economic impact through poor educational outcomes. They are identified in the World Health Organization (WHO) 2020 goals for neglected tropical diseases as target renewed effort to ameliorate their global public health burden mass drug administration (MDA) water hygiene improvement. In this chapter, we review underlying biology epidemiology of three causative intestinal nematode species that mostly considered under STH umbrella term. We efforts model transmission cycle these helminths populations effects preventative chemotherapy on control elimination. Recent modelling shows different epidemiological characteristics parasitic make up group can lead quite distinct responses any given form MDA. When connected with models treatment cost-effectiveness, potentially powerful tool informing policy. A number shortcomings identified; lack critical types data understanding diagnostic sensitivities hamper test hence improve models.

This is a very important result in the sense that HIV infection is very deadly in combination with TB infection. Here, one more interesting result is that both the disease cannot remain in the population even though the basic reproduction number is more than one for both the diseases. Only a disease can remain present in the population for a long time even if basic reproduction number is more than one for both diseases.

title: Species Interactions May Help Explain The Erratic Periodicity Of Whooping Cough Dynamics
abstract: Incidence of whooping cough exhibits variable dynamics across time and space. The periodicity this disease varies from annual to five years in different geographic regions both developing developed countries. title: Phenotypic Differences In Viral Immune Escape Explained By Linking Within-Host Dynamics To Host-Population Immunity

Q38: One major conclusion from this study is that if malaria exists in a population, there is persistence of trypanosomiasis even when the basic reproduction number for trypanosomiasis is below unity. Once trypanosomiasis is reduced, malaria prevalence increases and the reduction in trypanosomiasis indicates a reduced number of contacts with the tsetse fly when the individual is sick with malaria. Both diseases coexist if their basic reproduction numbers are close to each other. When protection against trypanosomiasis is enforced, the tsetse fly will need to bite more to keep the disease in the population. This would imply an increased number of bites per unprotected individual.

Q4: Parasite adaptations to within-host competition
title: Parasite Adaptations To Within-Host Competition
abstract: Competition between parasite species or strains within hosts is a major evolutionary force in infections. In response, parasites exhibit diverse array of strategies that improve their chances growth reproduction over competitors. This Review describes three types competition face (exploitation, apparent and interference), identifies successful for confronting these discusses whether are true adaptations to competition. Although many studies multiple infections have focused on disease outcomes (e.g. virulence), rather than the particular adapted response ensuing competitive interactions, ultimately responsible shaping interest. Q4: The biogeography of polymicrobial infection
title: The Biogeography Of Polymicrobial Infection
abstract: Microbial communities are spatially organized in both the environment and human body. Although patterns exhibited by these described microbial biogeography, this discipline has previously only considered large-scale, global patterns. By contrast, fine-scale positioning of a pathogen within an infection site can greatly alter its virulence potential. In Review, we highlight importance considering spatial study polymicrobial infections discuss targeting biogeography as therapeutic strategy.

title: Human Seasonal Influenza Under Covid-19 And The Potential Consequences Of Influenza Lineage Elimination

title: Impact Of Enhanced Tuberculosis Diagnosis In South Africa: A Mathematical Model Of Expanded Culture And Drug Susceptibility Testing
journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
abstract: South Africa has high rates of tuberculosis (TB), including multidrug-resistant (MDR) and extensively drug-resistant (XDR) strains. Expanding access to culture drug susceptibility testing (DST) for TB diagnosis may help control this epidemic, but the potential impact existing novel diagnostics is uncertain. By fitting World Health Organization epidemiological estimates, we developed a compartmental difference-equation model TB/HIV epidemic among African adults. Performing DST in 37% new cases 85% previously treated was projected save 47,955 lives (17.2% reduction mortality, 95% simulation interval (S.I.) 8.9-24.4%), avert 7,721 MDR-TB (14.1% reduction, S.I. 5.3-23.8%), prevent 46.6% deaths (95% 32.6-56.0%) over 10 years. Used alone, expanded did not reduce XDR-TB incidence, they enhanced transmission-reduction strategies, such as respiratory isolation. In Africa, expanding could substantially TB, particularly MDR-TB, mortality. Control will require additional interventions, which be by improved diagnosis.

abstract: Detention and removal of unauthorised immigrants by United States (U.S.) Immigration Customs Enforcement (ICE) has steadily increased despite declining rates migration. ICE detainees are held in overcrowded detention centres, often without due process deprived adequate food, sanitation, medical care. Conditions contribute to malnutrition increase the likelihood infectious disease exposure, including tuberculosis (TB). TB infection interacts with Type 2 Diabetes (DM2), disproportionately affecting individuals who routinely targeted federal immigration practices. When two diseases interact exacerbate one another within a larger structural context, thereby amplifying multiple interactions, this is called syndemic. In paper, we examine as pathway bidirectional risks for interactions between DM2 among detainees. Drawing from literature on conditions, TB, along U.S.-Mexico border, propose an ICE-TB-DM2 syndemic model. We present map displaying our proposed model demonstrate spatial application theory context detention, strengthening growing scholarship syndemics incarceration removal.

abstract: Abstract This paper presents a mathematical model of HIV and malaria co-infection transmission dynamics. Optimal control strategies such as preventive, anti-malaria antiretroviral (ARV) treatments are considered into the to reduce co-infection. We also obtain two basic reproduction ratios corresponding diseases. It was found that equilibrium is locally asymptotically stable whenever their respective numbers less than one. conducted sensitivity analysis determine dominant factor controlling transmission. sic Then, optimal theory for derived analytically by using Pontryagin Maximum Principle. title: Fighting The Public Health Burden Of Aids With The Human Pegivirus
abstract: Abstract Highly active antiretroviral therapy has revolutionized the battle against human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (HIV/AIDS). From its current global rollout, HIV/AIDS morbidity and mortality been greatly reduced, yet there exists substantial interest in development of new therapies to further mitigate health burden inhibit any fallout from drug resistance. One potential intervention is pegivirus (HPgV). HPgV not known cause disease, most remarkably it shown delay progression HIV AIDS. However, benefit increasing prevalence community HIV-infected men remains unknown at public level. We evaluated utility biovaccination for mitigating using mathematical models. Importantly, our work considers concern that will, itself, evolve become disease-causing by permitting mutant strains potentially arise during treatment. Our findings show rates 12.5%‚Äì50% annually could prevent 4.2‚Äì23.6 AIDS incidences 3.3‚Äì18.8 deaths, save 2.9‚Äì18.6 disability-adjusted life years per 1,000 people. Together, these indicate be an effective reducing mortality, thus warrants exploration.

abstract: Preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is highly effective for preventing human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, but risk compensation (RC) in men who have sex with (MSM) raises concerns about increased sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The Center Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC's) PrEP guidelines recommend biannual STI screening, which may reduce incidence by treating STIs that would otherwise remain undiagnosed. We investigated these two counteracting phenomena.With a network-based mathematical model of HIV, Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG), Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) transmission dynamics among MSM the United States, we simulated uptake following prescription indications HIV/STI screening recommendations CDC guidelines. Scenarios varied coverage (the proportion indicated received it), RC (a reduction per-act probability condom use), interval.In our reference scenario (40% coverage, 40% RC), 42% NG CT be averted over next decade. Such improved techniques are used in developed countries because of their superior speed and/or sensitivity. However, the potential impact of implementing additional or improved diagnostic techniques on TB control efforts in resourcelimited settings has not been widely studied.

Q4: Interactions between serotypes of dengue highlight epidemiological impact of cross-immunity
Q12_2_TEXT: multi-strain model only
title: Interactions Between Serotypes Of Dengue Highlight Epidemiological Impact Of Cross-Immunity
journal: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
abstract: Dengue, a mosquito-borne virus of humans, infects over 50 million people annually. Infection with any the four dengue serotypes induces protective immunity to that serotype, but does not confer long-term protection against infection by other serotypes. The immunological interactions between are central importance in understanding epidemiological dynamics and anticipating impact vaccines. We analysed 38-year time series 12 197 serotyped infections from hospital Bangkok, Thailand. Using novel mechanistic models represent different hypothesized immune serotypes, we found strong evidence provides substantial short-term cross-protection (approx. 1-3 years). This is first quantitative exists since human experimental studies performed 1950s. These findings will strategies for designing vaccine studies, future multi-strain modelling efforts, our evolutionary pressures disease systems.

Q39: it has been long reported that the majority of measles-related deaths are not due to the measles virus itself, but to secondary infections caused by the associated immunosuppression, hence the importance of taking into account IA into the broader field of epidemic mathematical modelling. In this work, we give a first step towards bridging this gap by incorporating the possibility of measles-induced IA into standard models of epidemic spreading for an arbitrary infectious disease co-occurring with measles outbreak; "In spite of this wealth of modelling approaches [[to modeling measles]], there is a crucial aspect of measles that is still systematically neglected and that has the potentiality to be more harmful than the outbreaks themselves: immune amnesia (IA)."

title: Immune Amnesia Induced By Measles And Its Effects On Concurrent Epidemics
journal: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
abstract: It has been recently discovered that the measles virus can damage pre-existing immunological memory, destroying B lymphocytes and reducing diversity of non-specific cells infected host. In particular, this implies previously acquired immunization from vaccination or direct exposition to other pathogens could be partially erased in a phenomenon named ‚Äòimmune amnesia‚Äô, whose effects become particularly worrisome given actual rise anti-vaccination movements. title: Chaos Versus Noisy Periodicity: Alternative Hypotheses For Childhood Epidemics
abstract: Whereas case rates for some childhood diseases (chickenpox) often vary according to an almost regular annual cycle, the incidence of more efficiently transmitted infections such as measles is variable. Three hypotheses have been proposed account fluctuations. (i) Irregular dynamics result from random shocks systems with stable equilibria. (ii) The intrinsic correspond biennial cycles that are subject stochastic forcing. (iii) Aperiodic fluctuations epidemiology. Comparison real world data and epidemiological models suggests epidemics inherently chaotic. Conversely, extent which chickenpox outbreaks approximate a yearly cycle depends inversely on population size.

Q17: HIV infects vital cells in the human immune system such as helper T cells (specifically CD4+ T cells), macrophages, and dendritic cells. As it hijacks the T cells that help keep the immune system working, HIV is particularly devastating to immune health. In the process of replication, the virus destroys increasing numbers of T cells. The T cells of an important part of the immune system are annihilated, leaving the body open to opportunistic infections. The immune system is thus deteriorated and no longer fulfils its role of fighting infections and diseases. Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a term for the most advanced stages of HIV infection
Q21: TB is usually acquired by inhaling TB bacteria from the surrounding air. All the infected people are not equally infectious and generally, it is only people with TB of the throat or lungs who are infectious. The bacteria get released in air by a carrier with active TB through coughing, sneezing or talking. Most infections do not have symptoms, in that case it is known as latent tuberculosis and people with latent TB do not spread the disease. Inhaling only a few of these germs is sufficient to get infected. About one quarter of the world–≤–Ç‚Ñ¢s population is infected with TB, while most are in latent phase

Q38: The TB only and HIV only models have globally stable disease-free equilibria when their corresponding reproduction number is less than unity. For a reproduction number greater than unity, the endemic equilibria also exist and are locally asymptotically stable. The full HIV-TB co-infection model is shown to have a locally asymptotically stable disease-free equilibrium when R0 < 1. The HIV only and TB only equilibrium exist and are locally asymptotically stable when RH0 > 1, RT0 < 1 and RH0 < 1, RT0 > 1, respectively.

Therefore, it is difficult to identify the correct initiation of ART with TB treatment.

title: Covid-19 And Dengue Co-Infection In Brazil: Optimal Control And Cost-Effectiveness Analysis
abstract: A mathematical model for the co-interaction of COVID-19 and dengue transmission dynamics is formulated analyzed. The sub-models are shown to be locally asymptotically stable when respective reproduction numbers below unity. title: An Agent-Based Model Simulation Of Influenza Interactions At The Host Level: Insight Into The Influenza-Related Burden Of Pneumococcal Infections
abstract: Host-level influenza virus-respiratory pathogen interactions are often reported. Although the exact biological mechanisms involved remain unelucidated, secondary bacterial infections known to account for a large part of influenza-associated burden, during seasonal and pandemic outbreaks. Those probably impact microorganisms' transmission dynamics public health toll. Mathematical models have been widely used examine epidemics control measures. However, most overlooked interaction phenomena ignored other co-circulating pathogens.Herein, we describe novel agent-based model (ABM) with another respiratory pathogen. The interacting microorganism can persist in population year round (endemic type, e.g. bacteria) or cause short-term annual outbreaks (epidemic winter viruses). framework enables precise formalization pathogens' natural histories complex within-host phenomena. As case study, this ABM is applied well-known virus-pneumococcus interaction, which several proposed. Different mechanistic hypotheses simulated resulting virus-induced pneumococcal infection (PI) burden assessed.This generates realistic data both pathogens terms weekly incidences PI cases, carriage rates, epidemic size timing. abstract: The Xpert MTB/RIF test enables rapid detection of tuberculosis (TB) and rifampicin resistance. World Health Organization recommends for initial diagnosis in individuals suspected having multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) or HIV-associated TB, many countries are moving quickly toward adopting Xpert. As roll-out proceeds, it is essential to understand the potential health impact cost-effectiveness diagnostic strategies based on Xpert.We evaluated economic consequences implementing five southern African countries--Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland--where drug resistance TB-HIV coinfection prevalent. title: Cost-Effectiveness Of Hepatitis C Treatment For People Who Inject Drugs And The Impact Of The Type Of Epidemic; Extrapolating From Amsterdam, The Netherlands
abstract: Background People who inject drugs (PWID) are disproportionally affected by the hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. The efficacy of HCV treatment has significantly improved in recent years with introduction direct-acting antivirals (DAAs). However, DAAs more costly than pegylated-interferon and ribavirin (PegIFN/RBV). We aimed to assess cost-effectiveness four strategies among PWID scale-up. Methods An individual-based model was used describing HIV transmission disease progression PWID. considered two epidemiological situations. A declining epidemic, based on situation Amsterdam, Netherlands, a stable as observed other settings. Data incidence, prevalence, setting uptake were derived from data Amsterdam. assessed incremental ratio (ICER, costs ‚Ç¨/quality-adjusted life year (QALY)) strategies: 1) PegIFN/RBV; 2) sofosbuvir/RBV for genotype 2‚Äì3 dual DAA 1‚Äì4; 3) Dual all genotypes; 4) 3x uptake. title: Screening For Hepatitis D And Peg-Interferon Over Tenofovir Enhance General Hepatitis Control Efforts In Brazil
abstract: Background Hepatitis D virus (HDV), which requires the presence of hepatitis B (HBV), is a deadly yet neglected disease that rapidly leads to liver cancer and disease-induced mortality. This co-dependence creates complex transmission dynamics make it difficult predict efficacy interventions aimed at HBV and/or HDV control in endemic regions, such as certain municipalities Brazil, where up 65% HBV-infected persons are co-infected. Methodology We created mathematical model captures joint HDV, incorporating mother-to-child, sexual household transmission. With an aim minimize number total infections mortality 2027, we then determined optimal strategies for Brazil its sub-regions under constrained budget, was dynamically allocated among screening, treatment, newborn adult vaccination, awareness programs. Three treatment options were considered, namely: Tenofovir, PEGylated-Interferon, nucleic acid polymers (NAP). Results The additional cost screening use more expensive PEGylated-Interferon offset by not wasting resources on treating co-infected with Tenofovir. introductory price NAP must be less than $16,000 per course become competitive Tenofovir Brazil. Conclusion Additional beneficial, even low regions recommend wherever possible, both HDV. If available abundance, co-infections 4-year mono-infections recommended.

Q4: Optimal Control Strategy for TB-HIV/AIDS Co-Infection Model in the Presence of Behaviour Modification
Q17: The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infects cells of immune system such as helper T cells (specifically CD4+ T cells), macrophages, and dendritic cells. HIV compromises the human immune system and reduces the ability of the body to fight back infections and diseases. The most advanced stages of HIV infection is usually called Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). AIDS is one of the leading causes of death worldwide that is affecting virtually every nation. Even if HIV/AIDS is not permanently curable, main methods used to fight against it are preventive mechanisms (which include: abstinence, faithfulness and protection) which mainly rely on the level of behavioral change of the population, and providing Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) for those infected.
Q20_11_TEXT: Tuberculosis (TB) is the second leading cause of death in the world next to the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). It particularly affects the lungs (pulmonary TB) but can also affect other organs of the body such as kidney, brain, blood, bones, glands (extra-pulmonary TB) [1–≤–Ç‚Äú4]. Not all individuals infected by TB develop active TB. Only around 10% of those infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis develop active TB disease and become infectious. Whereas, around 90% of the people infected with the bacteria remain latently infected and individuals in the latent stage do not transmit TB. However, there is a high risk of developing an active TB for individuals whose immune system is weakened due to the presence of HIV, malnutrition or diabetes. Infected individuals can be treated through anti-TB drugs such as Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol and Streptomycin.

Q17: It basically attacks the lungs (pulmonary TB), but can also affect the central nervous system, circulatory system, the genital-urinary system, bones, joints and even the skin. Tuberculosis can spread through cough, sneeze, speak, kiss or spit from active pulmonary TB persons. It can also spread through use of an infected person–≤–Ç‚Ñ¢s unsterilized eating utensils and in rare cases a pregnant woman with active TB can infect her foetus (vertical transmission). Transmission can only occur from people with active TB but not latent TB. This transmission from one person to another depends upon the number of infectious droplets expelled by a carrier, the effectiveness of ventilation, duration of the exposure and virulence of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis strain. The chain of transmission can therefore be broken by isolating patients with active disease and starting effective anti-tuberculosis therapy.
